title: #FutureProofAfrica: Putting humanity back into exponential technology
text:

You might think that humans wouldn’t be at the forefront of a summit about disruptive technologies and artificial intelligence – but speakers at SingularityU South Africa believe that machines won’t be replacing us any time soon.

In fact, with the rise of AI, disruptive technologies and mixed reality, it is believed to be enhancing the human experience, augmenting our resources instead of replacing them - specifically through industries like energy, education, agriculture and communication.

While you might think these innovations sound like they come out of science fiction novels, the technology is technically already here.

“We will see a lot in the next 15 years,” says Shayne Mann, co-CEO of Singularity University South Africa, at the opening of the summit.

WATCH: You know it's bad for humans when the robots that replaced them at this Japanese hotel get fired

And the main message? Don’t get left behind. This is a fear that’s prevalent across multiple industries, creating a gold rush for startups with spectacular ideas for the future – but not everyone can be Uber or Airbnb.

The billionaires of the future will be entrepreneurs who can solve a billion people’s problems according to Mann, because innovation crosses the tipping point to mainstream when there really is a need.

As Laila Pawlak pointed out, from SingularityU Nordic, it all depends on what we spend our time on – the iBeer app which makes your phone look like you’re drinking the golden liquid was downloaded 20 million times – no other species uses technology on such pointless endeavours.

Instead we should be focusing on the world’s most urgent to-do list – the UN Sustainable Development Goals. For Pawlak we have to rehumanise our technology, especially with the exponential development of computing power that’s surpassing human brainpower that hasn’t had an upgrade over thousands of years.

WATCH: Robots finally replacing humans? Meet Tokyo's digital security guards

But are we building castles in the air?

“Never before has every one of us had the opportunity to change the path of where we end up,” says Pawlak, “it all depends what we decide to spend our time on when we wake up in the morning.”

Another revolutionising technology that’s ever-expanding is the mobile smartphone, says computer scientist and former director of programme management at Microsoft Ramez Naam. By 2025, there will be 500 million mobile internet users in Africa, the continent that’s currently the least-connected in the world.

But this open space provides a lot of innovative thinking and opportunities for new ways to connect – which should be led by Africans themselves.

Local South African tech hero Stafford Masie – who helped forge a Google presence in Africa – is more focused on the practicality of tech rather than it looking ‘pretty’. Pushing machine learning into retail and calling artificial intelligence our ‘superpowers’, but inequality remains its weakness.

“We hear about AI’s negative impacts, but that’s not because of AI, but because of a lack of imagination from humanity.”

“It’s not to do more with fewer humans – we need to do more by augmenting our human resources.”
